title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

story: TWO Selkirk companies have combined to help make more than , face shields for hospitals and local businesses.Cademuir Engineering and Eadie Bros and Co have worked together since the start of April to supply D-printed visors, of which , have been sent to Selkirk-based workwear distributor Guthrie Group.The Guthrie Groups Selkirk manager Alan Skeldon said: ldquoIts great to have local businesses with the ability to make face shields, allowing us to supply to local healthcare facilities.A club of engineering enthusiasts based in Edinburgh, called Edinburgh Shield Force, contacted Eadie Bros for help making personal protective equipmentfor frontline workers.The engineers needed headbands for the face shields they were distributing to Scottish healthcare workers, including those at the Borders General Hospital.Using Eadie Brosrsquo injection-moulding tool, Cademuir made the headbands using state-of-the art equipment which enables each part to be robotically handled, minimising contamination risk and increasing the production rate to , a day.Cademuir Engineering production manager Marc Phaup said: ldquoIts fantastic to be involved in this important project for our NHS, along with supplying local businesses like Guthrie Group.ldquoThere are a lot of dferent groups who have come together to achieve the goal of getting PPE to our frontline workers.A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Shield Force added: ldquoThis project has only been possible because of the combined experience of our team, the tireless dedication of our volunteers and the flexibility and hard work of our partners Eadie Bros and Co and Cademuir Engineering.Edinburgh Shield Force is relying on a fundraising appeal, which you can access through this link.

title: man-shows-off-160-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A BORDERS man has come forward with a -year-old copy of a local newspaper.Mitchell Johnston, of Peebles, spotted last weekrsquos articlein the Peeblesshire Newsdocumenting council leader Shona Haslamrsquos surprise discovery while renovating her new house.Mrs Haslam unearthed an edition of the Peebles Newsdated February , , when tidying up the old courthouse at Peebles High Street.But now Mr Johnston, , wishes to showcase one of his own prized possessions ndash a copy of the Peeblesshire Advertiserfrom December , .Mr Johnston, a retired member of the merchant navy, said the paper had originally belonged to his uncle John Somerville, who emigrated to Canada in about  and became the manager of a mill.Mr Johnston said Somerville, born in , died in . Ten years later, following the death of Somervillersquos we, the paper was handed to Mr Johnston.ldquoI suppose itrsquos quite nice to look at it and it reminds me of my uncle coming here for holidays, said Mr Johnston.

title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

title: gala-rfc-hails-generosity-fans-1-000-goes-foodbank
story: GALASHIELS rugby players have raised more than pound, for the local foodbank ndash and delivered carloads of supplies.Over two successive weekends, Gala RFC invited supporters to drop off food at the gates of Scott Park.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoEveryonersquos generosity was fantastic.The weekend of April - saw nearly pound left by players, committee members, supporters and the general public ndash in addition to bags of groceries.The second weekend of collections, on May , raised pound ndash including a bottle of coins totalling pound from residents at Abbotsford Court.Mr Dalgleish said: ldquo[Captain] Euan Dods and [vice captain] Rex Jeffrey and other volunteers were collecting the food and donations at Scott Park, and then the bags were delivered to St Peterrsquos Church for the foodbank.ldquoThe bottle of coins donated by the folk at Abbotsford Court was pound ndash they donrsquot have a lot of money to give out but when they found out there was pound in the bottle they actually topped it up to pound.Galashiels Foodbank co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe are really thrilled to have all this local support.ldquoNearly pound, was raised in two weekends, and Herculean amounts of food ndash two carloads of food both weekends ndash so our stocks are right up to where we want them to be, which is wonderful.ldquoIn times of hardship people are thinking of each other. The public have really got their support behind this initiative and they just came along with food and money.ldquoBefore COVID, we were giving out maybe  carrier bags of food a week."At [the viruss peak] about two weeks ago we gave out  ndash a fourfold increase in demand.And the foodbank is not the only local charity to benefit from the generosity of the rugby club players.Gala Menrsquos Shed, whose members are making face visors for care workers, was the grateful recipient of a pound donation by the rugby club.Scottish Borders Menrsquos Shed developer Ross Hall described the donation as "fantastic".He said: "It took us over a wee setback in terms of supply, and Gala stepped in at just the right time to help us make more visors."So we had a wee break due to funding and now wersquore back on track. Fantastic news."

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: uk-government-refuses-share-galashiels-virus-results
story: THE UK Government has refused to sendstatistics to the Border relating to coronavirus tests carried out in Galashiels this month.The army ran a temporary testing facilityfor self-isolating key workers and their relatives at the Netherdale car park in the first week of May.But a UK Government spokesperson told this newspaper that the number of people seen at ldquoinidual test sites would not be disclosed.A follow-up request for further details on the Netherdale centre was also turned down this week.Details included whether an extension had been granted.The pop-up facility was one of dozens set up earlier this month as part of the UK Governments push for more testing. The Borders centre was scheduled to run between May  and May .Self-isolating key workers with symptoms were eligible for tests, as were their relatives living under the same roof.These are the questions which the Border posed to the UK Government on May :How many people have visited the Galashiels testing centre so far How many of those have received a positive diagnosis for the virus How do the number of visitors to the site in Galashiels compare to those in other mobile centres established in Scotland How do the number of positive cases confirmed at the Galashiels site compare to other centres in Scotland What further advice treatment is offered to those who test positive at a drive through centre Will the government extend theof time the town has this mobile testing facility beyond May  As the sites are only open to those showing signs of the virus or who are living with someone with symptoms, what is the purpose of these tests

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has saidthe UK Governmentrsquos furlough scheme willbe extended until the end of October.But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: borders-actor-jack-lowden-narrates-bbc-football-documentary

title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

title: golfers-raise-10-000-peebles-golf-club
story: GOLFERS have donated more than pound, to help Peebles Golf Club while the course is closed.The clubs fundraising drive, launched after the coronavirus lockdown, collected more than pound, last month.Les Biscomb, of the clubs sponsorship sub-committee, hailed the generosity of donors.Reflecting on the campaign so far, he said: ldquoItrsquos been a tremendous success."Unlike golf clubs south of the border, Scottish courses remain closed ndash meaning clubhouse coffers continue to struggle.But the idea of setting up a fundraiser in Peebles has already been vindicated, according to Mr Biscomb.He said: "As a team, we came up with the idea of, while wersquore in lockdown, our members might have vastly reduced income ndash theyrsquore being paid to work at home or are pensioners ndash but therersquos nowhere to spend your money at the moment."You canrsquot go to golf, you canrsquot go down the pub, you canrsquot go to restaurants, many people arenrsquot driving anywhere, so we thought, while wersquore in lockdown, why donrsquot we ask the members in Peebles, who are kindhearted and generous, to put something each month towards a crowdfunder.Comments by donors on the website include, Have my coffee money for the coming month otherwise Irsquoll probably fritter it away and Glad to donate again to ensure our club survives.The sub-committee originally set a target of pound, each month, but received more than pound, in April.Mr Biscomb said: ldquoWe would have been delightedwersquod raised the pound, but in the very first month alone we got to pound,."Some of those were one-offs, so people just wanted to join in with the giving and the spirit of helping the club but even so,you look at May, wersquore already at pound,.ldquoWe were hoping for this to continue for two or three months, pound, a month, just to add in the coffers."This isnrsquot funding thatrsquos needed immediately ndash from a cash perspective, Peebles is doing well."This is really for the quiet periods. Once we turn the corner into next year, thatrsquos really when we might need this money, in the quieter days.ldquoBut who knows whatrsquos going to happen with lockdown, and when wersquore going to get cash back through other means, like the bar and catering, and visitors.Currently, all club staff are on furlough, with the exception of head greenkeeper Steve Borthwick.ldquoSteversquos going a fantastic job, said Mr Biscomb. "The course is in magnicent condition ndash it is very tempting to get out there.Meanwhile, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that golf clubs in England can re-open, as long as social distancing guidelines are followed.Mr Biscomb conceded he is "quite jealous", but indicated he is satisfied with the Scottish rules.He said: ldquoIrsquod love to get out on the golf course. But equally, we understand that the Scottish Government is not ready because the stats are not there."Theyrsquore not comfortable with opening golf clubs and we have to respect that."Hopefully, in a few weeksrsquo time,the number [of virus cases] comes down, we can start to get out in ones and twos."For now, we have to live with it and be sensible."Wersquore in the eighth week already ndash another couple of weeks wonrsquot do any harm."Itrsquos achievable to be sensible for another few weeks.Donations to Peebles Golf Club can be made via: www.justgiving crowdfunding pgcmembersappealfund

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: subway-store-galashiels-busy-since-re-opening
story: SUBWAY in Galashiels has re-opened for takeaway and delivery.The sandwich store, which had closed due to coronavirus restrictions, welcomed customers back this week.The Channel Street premises opened its doors again on Monday , applying social distancing guidance and using protective gear.Store supervisor Imran Han said the shop has been "busy".

title: borders-lib-dems-select-ettrick-roxburgh-berwickshire-candidate
story: THE Liberal Democrats have selected a candidate for next years Holyrood election.Jenny Marr will stand for the Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire constituency ndash currently held by Conservative Rachael Hamilton.The former Selkirk High pupil said: "Irsquom thrilled to have been chosen to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire for the Scottish Liberal Democrats."We are living in extraordinary times and I have been blown away by how communities across the Borders have rallied to support each other."The most important thing we can do as politicians and political parties is to provide assistance to anyone that needs it, learn from our experiences and work to address inequalities which have manest."The vote is set to take place on Thursday, May  of next year.

title: borders-based-msp-introduces-online-advice-surgeries
story: A BORDERS-BASED MSP is introducing video surgeries for his constituents.Paul Wheelhouse, who represents the South of Scotland, has had to temporarily close his Hawick office due to the coronavirus outbreak.But from next Friday, Borderers will be able to have a face-to-face meeting ndash without leaving their homes.Mr Wheelhouse said: "Video advice surgeries will be secure and confidential. Constituents will be able to talk to me as though we were sitting down together in person."I fully appreciate that many people do not have video-conferencing technology, or do not even have the internet in their home. For those people, my office is still contactable by telephone at this time."The online advice surgeries are to complement, not replace, other forms of communication. I would strongly encourage anyone who needs my support to get in touch, either by email or phone, and myself and my team will assist in any way we can."Mr Wheelhousersquos first online surgery will take place from pm on Friday, May .To make an appointment, email: paul.wheelhouse.msp@parliament.scot

title: 75-students-without-laptop-get-device-borders-college
story: BORDERS College has loaned laptops to  students who did not have regular access to a suitable device at home.With face-to-face classes cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, learning has been taking place remotely.Student who did not have adequate laptops of their own have been allowed to borrow from the Galashiels campus.Sport and exercise student Harrison Dixon, from Earlston, said he was "delighted" with the scheme.He said: ldquoMy personal computer is old and struggling to work with some of the new applications and online resources that we are now using, so I spoke with my course tutor who made me aware of the loan scheme, and I was delighted when it was delivered last week."Having the laptop will allow me to continue with my studies remotely.The college says it has loaned a total of  laptops, including those allocated through its bursary programme.Head of IT Scott Moncrieff said: ldquoBefore the college closed, we were able to prepare and distribute  laptops to students for use."Since lockdown, we have had an additional  requests, which we have been able to fulfil.ldquoAny students who find themselves in the situation that continuing their education is not possible, because they donrsquot have an appropriate device, should contact their course tutor or achievement coach, and they will make the appropriate arrangements.

title: coronavirus-got-feel-optimistic
story: As the coronavirus outbreak continues to keep its hold on the UK, there are some rays of hope and developments to feel optimistic about.The PA news agency looks at some of the progression that is being made in the fight to get Covid- under control.ndash Antibody testvw,vw,px, px"Public Health Englandhas approved an antibody test from the pharmaceutical giant Roche after experts at its Porton Down facility gave it the green light.Previously described by Prime Minister Boris Johnson as a ldquogame changer, the test picks up cases where somebody has had coronavirus in the past, and can be used on people who experienced no symptoms.Experts believe those who have had Covid- develop a degree of immunity, meaning the test could prove a useful tool for helping to ease lockdown restrictions.ndash VaccineMany researchers across the world are racing to develop a vaccine for the virus. A small number have started clinical trials in humans, including a team at the University of Oxford.Studies of the vaccine candidate in rhesus macaques showed that the animals developed antibodies, and a single vaccination dose was also effective in preventing damage to the lungs."EMA is in continuous discussion with#developers and has had contacts with them about  vaccines  more than  therapeutics," said Marco Cavaleri, EMAs Head of Biological Health Threats  Vaccines Strategy, in a press briefing today. Full recording: https:t.co MrzPWuImdash EU Medicines AgencyMay , Experts believe results of the human trials could be ready by the middle of June.Despite Mr Johnson saying there is no guarantee of a vaccine, on Thursday the European Medicines Agencysaid licensed drugs to treat Covid- could be available in the next few months, and that a vaccine might be approved in early .ndash R numberAcademics at the University of Cambridge reported that the UKrsquos rate of reinfection, known as the R number, was now firmly under ..This is a goal the Prime Minister has set in order to keep gradually releasing the lockdown in the coming months.The R number represents the average number of people an infected person will pass the virus on to. It is also referred to as the reproduction number.ndash LockdownNations across the UK are looking at how and when lockdown restrictions may be eased, with England outlining the most comprehensive plan.If you live in England, you can now spend more time exercising and relaxing outdoors ##You MUST continue to keep at least  metres away from anyone that you dont live with.More info ##https:t.co yqkGbvpN#StayAlert#Coronaviruspic sPrrgEDHmdash Department of Health and Social CareMay , After weeks of being told to stay at home, from Wednesday the measures in England were relaxed to allow people to spend more time outside, meet a friend at the park and view a potential new home.Unlimited exercise, sunbathing and meeting one person from another household in a public space has also been permitted, as long as the two-metre rule is respected, while golf clubs, tennis courts and angling were also given the green light.ndash What  has changed that may help lt spirits Sports fans who have been disappointed by the postponement of many events, including the Olympics and Euro , will be able to enjoy live football as the German Bundesliga restarts on Saturday, albeit behind closed doors.Keep your eyes on these guys ### https:t.co eGHwvJXHpic NfVYxrXAFtmdash Bundesliga EnglishMay , Soap fans will have welcomed the news that the makers of Coronation Street and Emmerdale are in the ldquofinal stages of working on plans for the soaps toto production.And EastEnders is set to resume filming by the end of June.On Thursday, the nation took to their doorsteps for the eighth week in a row to clap for NHS carers and key workers who have put their lives at risk fighting Covid-.Elsewhere, countries such as New Zealand and Australia have eased lockdown measures, with pubs in New South Wales opening to the public..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Coronavirus: What have we got to feel optimistic about

title: historic-borders-houses-feature-visitscotland-campaign
story: HISTORIC homes in the Borders are featuring in a social media campaign by VisitScotland.The tourist organisation has launched #AWindowOnScotland, which asks people to take a photo from their window.Traquair House, Peebles, is among the stately homes in the Borders taking part, with views from the th century Aikwood Tower, near Selkirk, also being shared across social media.Gillian Steele, chairwoman of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, said: "I donrsquot think people will necessarily forget we are here, but with us all looking out of our windows dreaming of that day when we can travel again, and indulge our passion for Scottish heritage, this campaign strikes a chord."VisitScotlandrsquos #AWindowOnScotland campaign provides us with a great visual opportunity to continue to promote our Houses, their gardens and their wildle from the same perspective as everyone at home."Irsquom encouraging all the Big Houses to take part, and I hope between the eleven of us we will give visitors a reminder of how beautul our Houses and gardens look this month."The campaigns hashtag has been used , times, with towns and villages across the Borders taking part.Historic buildings participating include Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, and Mellerstain House, near Kelso.VisitScotlands regional leadership director Paula Ward said: ldquoWersquore thrilled at the reaction to #AWindowOnScotland from residents across the Scottish Borders and heartened that businesses are engaging with the campaign and using the opportunity to share their windows on Scotland with the world during this challenging time.ldquoThe staycation market will be a key driver in the countryrsquos economic recovery and the many wonderful views people have been sharing while they stay at home will surely be an incentive for many to travel when the time comes.ldquoThe campaign is far from over and wersquod encourage residents and businesses to continue posting their views, however they may look, as it is all Scotland, to help lt the spirits of those at home and abroad.To join the campaign, take a photo of a view from your window and share it online using #AWindowOnScotland, then tag your location.

title: national-express-plans-resume-coach-services-july-1
story: National Express has started selling UK coach tickets as it plans to restart services on July .The tickets will be available for a "core coach network" andwill focus on large and medium-sized towns and cities.Revenue dropped about  per cent in April compared withthe same month last year, National Express revealed, as the Government advised Britons to keep away from public transport.Nevertheless, Ebitdawas positive and slightly ahead of expectations as National Express slashed costs by about pound million.What hasNational Express said In a statement to customers, National Express said: "We have extended the temporary suspension of our coach services."A restricted timetable is currently scheduled to resume from Wednesday, July , ."Please note, however, all services are subject to change depending on Government advice."For thosethat have an upcoming journey booked with us on or before June ,  and would like to amend your booking, you can do so for free, for travel any time in the next  months."There is no need to contact us straight away, just completeour ticket amendment formbefore your original outward journey and get back in touch with us when yoursquore ready to travel again."If you do not wish to amend your ticket to another date, we will provide a full refund. If you havenrsquot already done so, please completeour refund formand we will process your refund within  days."Please stay safe and well and, when the time is right, we look forward to welcoming you back on board."Where does National Express travel to The company runs coach services across the UK, including Manchester to Coventry, London to Worthing, Newcastle via Darlington to London, Liverpool to Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow to London, plus Bradford to London.

title: graphic-designer-reveals-inspired-borders-kids
story: A GRAPHIC designer is helping to keep families entertained during lockdown after creating free colouring packs.Kate Pearson, , who owns K Graphic Design, has created six art packs to help ease the boredom of being stuck indoors.Kate, of Peebles, said: "I absolutely love my job because I get to be creative every day."Each pack features dferent activities for children ndash and adults ndash including colouring, design, and games like word searches.Kate said: "Just before lockdown, I spoke to the pupils at my old primary school, Priorsford Primary School, about my career."I left feeling inspired by their enthusiasm and the idea of activity packs was born."She had planned to print the packs but wanted them to be accessible so made them digital ndash a decision which has paid off.The downloads page on her website has been visited more than , times in the last two months, she said.Kate ensured that each pack had something for everyone, with themes including rainbows and dinosaurs."They were designed with young people in mind, but have proved to be just as popular with adults ndash especially the dinosaur one," said Kate.Kate also owns Glass Bulldog Wedding Stationary, and with wedding fairs for  cancelled or postponed, both sides of her business have taken a knock."Ninety per cent of my bookings have been cancelled or postponed until next year ndash many of my suppliers are affected too," said Kate."I really feel for all businesses facing closure and couples postponing their weddings."Like everyone, the biggest challenge of COVID- is not seeing friends and family, but staying at home is such a small price to pay to stay safe ndash especially now lsquoNeighboursrsquo is back on five days a week!"Kate ed to Peebles only a few years ago, after enjoying multiple career roles including as a wedding planner and working for a London-based design agency.Looking to the future, Kate already has three new packs in mind and hopes to eventually print the activity books.She also hopes that once the Borders s to normal, many of her usual services will be back up and running, especially those catered for weddings and events."My clients range from small local start-ups to The Botanic Gardens and Amazon ndash no two days are the same," she said."Going freelance also means I can take my dog, Dr Frankenstein, to work. What more could you ask for "

title: free-listings-site-promotes-independent-business
story: Tom Harries has come up with a free listings site ndash Edinburgh Lockdown Economy ndash which features  local businesses and their lockdown offers.Since its recent launch, the website has attracted around , visitors.It features everything from childrenrsquos activity packs and online fitness classes to craft ale orders from local breweries.Tom and his team behind the project hope that visitors will discover something on their doorstep they didnrsquot know existed, providing businesses with much-needed revenues that could help them survive until the restrictions are lted.ldquoMy we is a doctor at the Western General Hospital and I could see that local businesses were offering food and other support to help front line staff cope, said Tom, a user experiencedesign consultant who has worked with companies including yell, Virgin Media Business and Lloyds Banking Group.He added: ldquoI realised that many local businesses were at risk and could do with some support, too, so I built the site as a one-stop shop to show the public who was still in operation and what they could buy or access.ldquoSince we launched, the response from the community has been phenomenal.ldquoThe iety of services still on offer was a shock to me so Irsquod encourage anyone to take a look and feel inspired. title: resilient-musselburgh-team-moves-due-increased-demand
story: The Resilient Musselburgh team was operating out of Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School but had to switch its hub to the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre for more space to meet its growing needs.The initiative involvesMusselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership, Wallyford Community Council, Whitecraig Community Council and East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities which are covering Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall.Stuart Baxter, Connected Communities manager, said: ldquoThe Connected Communities Base, co-ordinating the supply of food and services directed by Resilient Musselburgh, has moved to the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre .ldquoThe demand associated with the current Covid- crisis meant that the space available at Pinkie was insufficient and the move to MECLC allows greater space for storing necessary food and supplies, greater access to needed IT services and further space to allow additional staff to assist in the provision of these vital services to the most vulnerable in the community.He is working alongside community development officers Jane Cummings and Pamela Martin, and family support outreach worker Donna Doherty.They are supported by Musselburgh  Inveresk community councillors Irene Tait, Margaret Stewart and Bernard Harkins.Links to Wallyford and Whitecraig are maintained through regular contact with the chairpersons of their community councils, Alister Hadden and Shona Bennett.Mrs Stewart said: ldquoWe are currently working with a number of local businesses and organisations to provide the stock for emergency supplies including Tesco Musselburgh and the Pinkie Farm Shop.Thank you for reading this story. story: The film was made by the schoolrsquos film club, named Peely-wally Productions, in collaboration with Longniddry Parish Church, before lockdown began in March.The pupils planned, shot and edited the film as part of the th anniversary of VE Day.Initial plans were to have a premiere and afternoon tea at the church tomorrow.Howeever, coronavirus and the current restrictions meant that that could not take place.The premiere has instead moved online and will take place through the Zoom online video app at pm.The film will also be uploaded to the schoolrsquos YouTube channel.The film includes interviews with three East Lothian residents who grew up during the Second World War, all of whom are involved in Longniddry Parish Church in some way.Louise Marr, an English and film teacher at the secondary school in Prestonpans, said that she had bought a lot of bunting specially for the premiere event to decorate the hall but is thinking of displaying it in her window as part of her own celebrations on the day.She added: ldquoIn our own way, we will still be able to celebrate the end of the Second World War and think about the sacrices made by that generation. ldquoWe ran out of time for the final edit of the film but are very thankful for the work of a former pupil and PL film club member for four years, Alastair Clarke. ldquoAlastair is now studying filmmaking at the University of the Highlands and Islands. title: trademark-hairstyle-set-go-boost-charity
story: Ezra Bragg, , known as Ez, is putting his crowning glory in the hands of his we Jen, , tomorrowin aid of his employer ndash the Bethany Christian Trust which has a launched at pound, emergency appeal.She has admitted to ldquonever using cutters before in her le but is ready to do the head shave in the communal garden of their Inveresk Road home, cheered on by neighbours who will be observing social distancing rules from a balcony.Jen, a psychiatric nurse who has worked in the voluntary sector helping those who suffered from mental health issues, trauma and survivors of abuse in care, has set up a JustGiving page for donations.The couple have already smashed their pound target, with about pound raised.She said: ldquoEz has a big heart and wanted to try and do something to help the trust at this time. I have known him for more than  years and he has always had the same hairstyle. He is a little nervous about the head shave but feels it is a good cause, and a bit of fun. He has also delivered furniture to the trustrsquos charity shops and, as his background is in building, for the last four years, is one of two maintenance officers for the charityrsquos homeless units.Jen said: ldquoIf people can, please donate to a really wonderful cause. title: mekala-osborne-enjoys-outdoors-road-recovery
story: The image was posted on social media by close family friend Davie Martin, on behalf of the family, who described the image as ldquopeaceful.The caption alongside the image read: ldquoYes its our wee warrior Mekala outside in the hospital grounds for the first time in god knows how long.ldquoSo emotional looking at this just trying to imagine what Mekala is just sitting there thinking about. A penny for yer thoughts sweetheart. Your one special lassie.Mum Yvonne said: ldquoI wish I knew what your thoughts are toots. So, so proud of you. Very emotional Mummy tonight.Former Preston Lodge High School pupil Mekala, , was travelling through south-east Asia with a friend last autumn when she phoned home complaining of a sore throat.Over the coming days, and after being given antibiotics and painkillers, her condition worsened and she soon ended up in hospital in an induced coma after being diagnosed with bronchial pneumonia.Mekala, who lives in Wallyford, was then transferred to a hospital in Singapore for further treatment.A fundraising page to allow Yvonne and step-dad Jimmy to be by her bedside attracted donations from across East Lothian and beyond, raising over pound,.Mekala was flown back to the UK in November last year and transferred to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh for further treatment.She was transferred to the Astley Ainslie at the end of March where she is currently receiving rehab.Mekala is said to be doing really well, she is sitting up and had an assisted shower.Speaking to the Courier last month, Jimmy said: ldquoIt is absolutely amazing.ldquoWhen you look at the first photograph back in September of her lying in hospital in Da Nang [Vietnam] and she had a five per cent chance of survival and then look at her now.ldquoShe is still not the same Mekala we know but she is getting there.ldquoShe has got a big smile on her face and we FaceTime every night to keep in touch.ldquoShe is amazing and she can now move a couple of fingers on each hand.It is hoped Mekala will be home for Christmas.Thank you for reading this story. title: seal-pup-spotters-asked-share-photos
story: Zoologist Donald Malone, a former pupil of Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar Schools, will send them to friends at the Sea Mammal Research Unitat the University of St Andrews, who keep databases of seal images and attempt to identy iniduals from them.Mr Malone said: ldquoThis would help gain an idea of the number of both harbour and grey seals around the coast of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThey can also keep a lookout for pups, as harbour seals give birth in June and July and grey seals from September to December. Harbour seal pups shed their whitecoat in the womb before being born and so can be in the water and swim almost straight from birth. Females need to give birth on land though.ldquoGrey seal pups are born with the white lunugo fur and have to stay on land much more until they moult this off around three weeks after giving birth.He saidanyone spots a seal entangled in material such as fishing gear, they should contact British Divers Marine Le Rescuebdmlr.org.uk index.php, which has trained people in East Lothian who will try to capture and free the seal.Mr Malone, who studied zoology at University of Glasgow, has been through this training and has had to aid hundreds of seals all over the world.He was delighted to capture on camera a large group of around  seals, some pregnant, near the Musselburgh lagoons while out for his daily exercise on a cycle from his Edinburgh home.They were hauled out on exposed rocks, just offshore and past the lagoons, heading towards Prestonpans.Mr Malone said: ldquoHarbour seal numbers have actually been in quite drastic decline around Scotland, especially on the east coast, so it was good to see this big group of them.ldquoI am a bit of a fan of seals, having worked on numerous projects on them. story: THE Enormous Turnip is a well known story about the importance of working together.I have written a rhyming version of this traditional tale, which has its origins in Russian folklore.I have shared it with teachers and parents in East Lothian and beyond, and have also created a film, which you can find on my YouTube channel, in which I recite the story, with the written words displayed on the screen.The idea is that hopefully children will create a drawing, painting of a scene or character from the story, and send it in.A photo of a scene being acted out would work too.Itrsquos up to the children to use their creativity in any way they want.I will then add these images onto a new version of the film, where I will tell the story using the childrenrsquos artwork.After the summer I hope to turn all the artwork into a book, in which all the pictures made by the children will be included, along with the rhyming story.My hope is that it can be creative fun, but also that both book and the film could be a positive legacy of the lockdown with a well-known story bringing together children who use their imagination to create something together for posterity.If you are a parent, grandparent, teacher or look after children please do get in touch about how to get involved in this project, and I can send materials and links.Or alternatively, you could just read the story at bedtimeyou fancy.The Enormous Turnip In RhymeOnce there was a family who lived together in a wee houseAn old man, an old woman, their grandchildren, a dog, a cat, and a timid mouse.The house had a garden, so wonderful and green,Where the old man grew vegetables, the best yoursquove ever seen.One day he decided, to plant a turnip seed.So he went to his shed, to get the things he would need:A rake and a hoe, and his gardening gloves.Then he went to the garden, a place that he loves.Carrots and radishes already grew there,So he planted the turnip seed. Can you guess where In a patch of ground that was sunny and brightAnd sheltered from the frost that comes during the night.He watered the seed with his watering can,Then waited for it to grow, that gardening old man.And grow it did, that turnip seed,Under the ground, at an incredible speed.Soon bigger than an apple it grew,Then the size of a football, then the size of two.The turnip got bigger with each passing day,How much would it grow  Nobody could say.It grew from big into huge, and then enormous it became.Never in history had there been a turnip quite the same.At last it was ready to we.ldquoMy dear, my dear, please help meTo pull out this turnip, so we can eat it for tea.ldquoHow can I help  she asked the old man,ldquoWhen I pull the turnip, you pull me, as hard as you can.So she title: p1-deferrals-u-turn-schools-remain-closed-covid-19
story: Several parents had spoken out in anger after their Primary  deferral funding requests were rejected by the council, which last year had the worst record for approving the applications of any Scottish local authority.This year only two of  applications by parents were approved and of the  refused,  parents appealed.Now the council has said all  cases turned down for funding will be granted the money.However they made it clear the decision was because of the current Covid- pandemic and a review of their policy would be carried out at a later date.One mother told how her children were born two years apart but under the current council policy her youngest son would have had to start P this summer while her oldest, who was born in January, was allowed to defer for a year, was in P.She said: ldquoMy youngest was born at the end of December so they are fully two years apart yet I am not being allowed to defer their start at school and they will be only one year apart in education terms.Current legislation allows parents of children who are born in January and February to automatically receive funding for a delay in starting Primary One until they are five years old.Parents of children born between August and December, who would also start school aged four, can also defer their primary one start for a year but the council can refuse to pay for their nursery care.Last year, East Lothian Council approved  per cent of applications ndash the lowest percentage of any local authority in Scotland. This year the figure fell to less than  per cent.The council also refuses to allow children whose parents opt to keep them home and fund the nursery place themselves to remain in school nurseries.Parents who decide to pay for an additional year of nursery themselves to keep their children out for a year face bills of up to pound, and a hunt for alternative child care places.Another mum who was refused funding said she had initially been supported in her view that her child was too immature to start school by her nursery.But they withdrew that support after pressure from the councilrsquos education department, she said.ldquoThey were told that they couldnrsquot support us because we didnrsquot meet the council policy criteria and withdrew their support, she explained.ldquoOur views meant nothing and the impact on our child meant nothing.And other parents expressed fears that their children were being robbed of nursery experience because they have been in lockdown for some of the vital months they would have had and would have no transition into school.One mum said: Children who start school at -years-old already receive a year less nursery time than those who are older, that has been reduced further by the closure of nurseries.ldquoHow can we ask these young children to go from months at home with their family to suddenly starting primary one with no transition A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoconfirmed they have now agreed to approve all deferral requests for the year ahead.They said: ldquoAs a result of the ongoing closure of schools and nurseries, we have been reviewing applications for deferred entry to P, ahead of session  . title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, title: superhero-primary-school-teacher-message-difference
story: Alison Blevins, a primary four teacher at the school, posted a welcome back message on social media after the Easter holidays.It read: ldquoWelcome back to the summer term. title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE Dirleton Area Resilience Teamcontinues to serve its community, with requests to pick up shopping and prescriptions still coming in.It has also launched a new booking system to allow it to better serve its community and protect its volunteers.Its essentials community larder continues to flourish and has seen an entertainment section added.It now stocks books, CDs, DVDs and board games, with sections for both adults and children.Generous donations continue to be made of special food items such as crumbles, bakery treats and soups.DART is working with both the Saltire and Hi Awards, youth volunteer programmes that have allowed the group to include volunteering activities for young people.The Saltire Award is available for young people aged -.It is a nationally credited award that goes towards Scottish Credit and Qualications Framework .Volunteers will be allowed to be a part of DART and help complete requests such as delivering leaflets and fulfilling customer orders.The Hi Awards are for children aged five to . DART will be offering children between these ages at-home volunteering opportunities, such as letter writing and art, which will be sent to those self-isolating and shielding in the village.David Tait, lead co-ordinator for DART, said: ldquoWe now have a great opportunity for the youth in our community to feel part of this amazing organisation.ldquoWith the addition of the awards being nationally recognised and accredited, it was a no-brainer to follow through on this opportunity.ldquoIf any of our youth are interested in the Saltire or Hi Awards, please email your enquiry to Dart.Coordinators@outlook.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contactDART.coordinators@outlookor call .DunbarDunbarA FRIENDLY voice at the other end of the phone is being offered to people on their own during lockdown.Community resilience volunteers in Dunbar are urging people to get in touch evenit is simply for a chat.The townrsquos volunteers are already offering a range of services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions.In addition, there is also a chance for people to simply talk to someone. George Robertson, a member of the townrsquos community council and chairman of the Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , stressed the importance of the service.He said: ldquoIt is a really important aspect to the whole thing. I think it will become increasingly important as people get a bit stir crazy.ldquoObviously, a lot of people have friends and family nearby but there are quite a few who do not.ldquoWe need to be conscious that sometimes they are reluctant to ask for help.ldquoWe need to be vigilant for anyone looking for help so we can give a bit of TLC, support, help or a friendly voice on the end of the phone.George has been at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town. Dunbar, along with neighbouring West Barns, has been split into dferent sections, with a lead volunteer in each of the areas.The lead volunteers for the nine clusters ndash Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line ndash have an online meeting each fortnight to checkthere are any issues.George said: ldquoWe are still getting regular requests for shopping, prescriptions and the like.ldquoThere are also a few people who just ring up for a chat.ldquoThat is all ticking along quite nicely.Attention is also turning to how the community copes when lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A number of volunteers willto work as businesses reopen but George was confident that Dunbar and West Barns would continue to be there for people in need.He previously had to draw up a reserve list for volunteers when the coronavirus pandemic started and said there would be enough people to continue to offer support.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers at facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council at facebook Dunbar CommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderSHOPPING and prescriptions continue to be collected for residents in East Linton and surrounding villages.The Dunpender community resilience team, like many across the county, is offering a iety of services to help people in need during the coronavirus crisis.Judith Priest, chairwoman of the villagersquos community council, said things remained quiet but they were thereanyone was in need of assistance.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus is available on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as on eastlinton.uk.Last month, a flyer was delivered to each home in the area, which offered assistance in terms of shopping, prescriptions or people looking to talk to someone.For more information, call   and  .Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirTEAMS of volunteers are keeping in touch with each other throughout East Lothian to ensure they are helping people the best they can.Resilience groups have been set up in towns and villages throughout the county during the coronavirus outbreak.Volunteers have come forward to help vulnerable members of the community with any assistance they need.Chris Bruce, chairman of East Lammermuir Community Council, said they were continuing to work together.The community council covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks.Mr Bruce said: ldquoThere is a pretty good network of email contact, and people follow up with phone callsthere is something particular.ldquoIt is right across East Lothian and is really good.Contact detailsMore information on the help available in the East Lammermuir area is available from the grouprsquos website, eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk, which also contains a list of the community councillors.Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneA NEW website has been set up to provide people in Gullane with the latest information relating to the coronavirus.The Gullane Resilience Team, made up of volunteers from throughout the village, have been working hard since the outbreak of restrictions due to the global pandemic.Now, a dedicated website has been set up to keep people up-to-date.A spokesman for the villagersquos resilience team said: ldquoThe Gullane Resilience Team have continued to serve the community but have noticed a settling down of demand.ldquoLorna Scott, our co-ordinator, has worked extremely hard and is developing the village hub for the distribution of food, the exchange of DVDs and childrenrsquos games every Tuesday, noon to pm, and Friday, .am to am.ldquoSeveral face shields were donated by Alun Joseph and were passed on to the Gullane Medical Centre and the Muirfield care home.ldquoBoth have reported that they are delighted with them.ldquoA new website, GullaneRT, has been set up which contains all the information regarding how our resources are being deployed and the services that can be provided by the team.Contact detailsFor more information, visit www.gullanert or contact the team on GullaneRteam@gmail or by telephoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Day Centre may be closed to its members due to the coronavirus crisis, but it is making sure they are being looked after in their homes.Some  of the day centrersquos  members are receiving sandwich lunches.The centre was established  years ago to improve the quality of le for older people who live independently in and around North Berwick.Normally, members would be brought to the centre by its own specially adapted bus once or twice a week.Now, its nine staff are delivering  lunches, five days a week, and all members are also getting free copies of the East Lothian Courier, thanks to the North Berwick resilience group fund.Care assistant Lisa Robertson said a lot of members were getting their lunch every day and those celebrating birthdays were also getting a special treat.In the past eight weeks, five members have received sweet treats to celebrate their birthdays, with the most recent being a -year-old woman.The Day Centre is also handing out quizzes, games and jigsaws to members, as well as having a chat on doorsteps ndash at a safe distance ndash where possible.Lisa said so far all of the centre members have stayed in good health but they are lonely and missing meeting other people.A team of around  volunteers are contacting members by telephone to have a chat and also find outany other help is needed.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Councilrsquos resilience group fund is being used to help volunteers get ready-made meals delivered to vulnerable residents in the town three days per week.Community council chair Judy Lockhart has arranged for voluntary organisation Home-Start East Lothian to provide two-course meals at a cost of pound. a day, and is using the fund to subsidise them for people wanting a meal every day of the week.As a result, someone wanting seven meals a week will only have to pay pound.The resilience fund can also offer financial assistance to those who need money to pay for these meals.Contact detailsPeople wishing to sign up for the service should phone the resilience group helpline on   or email communityresilience@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.ukOr you can visitwww.nbresilience
