story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Garvald.M J Richardson and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.GarvaldCOMMUNITY spirit has been praised in a rural part of East Lothian which is tackling the coronavirus.Garvald and Morham Community Council was one of the first to produce an emergency resilience plan, with the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team also being established.Since then, a leaflet has been hand delivered to each of the properties, with information also put online to keep people up-to-date with what is happening.Penny Short, co-ordinator of the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team, noted there were a number of issues they had to overcome, including the remoteness of some people living in the area.She said: ldquoBefore the coronavirus epidemic and subsequent lockdown hit we had already hand delivered a leaflet to every address in our ward explaining who we were and what the team could do, so that everyone in our area knew who to contactthey needed any help.ldquoOur team members have a WhatsApp Group and we keep in touch through that.ldquoSocial media has been a blessing through this time of social distancing!ldquoOnce lockdown was in place I set up a private Facebook page called Garvald Community which is for residents only.ldquoThis is a safe, supportive place where people can ask for help or assistance and hopefully find helpful advice and information such as messages from the government or information on food deliveries.ldquoInformation on food deliveries is pretty important as Garvald doesnrsquot have any shopsand for people who are self-isolating or shielding these food deliveries are essential.ldquoWe contacted ious food suppliers and co-ordinated delivery days and then passed on the details to the villagers.However, it is not just through social media that the group has reached out to people.An online form, which people can fill in outlining how they need assistance, is available on the villagersquos website.Penny added: ldquoWe are aware of any vulnerable people in our area and we are connected with our residents ndash whether through the Garvald Community Facebook page, the website or the villagersquos Neighbourhood Watch Scheme.ldquoBecause we are pretty remote and used to being cut off in bad weather our community is already pretty resilient and has always been supportive to everyone in the village.ldquoBut our wonderful community spirit has never been more evident than right now as everyone has come together to help each other and provide support with shopping, collecting prescriptions, offers of dog walking and other ways to help each other.ldquoWe have recently launched a group to make face masks for locals and lsquoscrubs bagsrsquo for NHS and care workers.ldquoNot for the first time I am so grateful to stay in Garvald and so proud of our fantastic community."Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.garvald.org.ukGford. Picture: Google MapsGfordGIFFORD volunteers this week trialled a new Soup And A Smile delivery service as they took hot lentil soup, a buttered roll and a fruit scone to households where there are older residents living alone.The plan is to provide lunch one day a week, as well as catch up with residents while observing social distancing rules.Nicola Goddard, from Lanterne Rouge cafeacute, offered her services to support the volunteer activity, which is provided free to the households.A spokesperson for Gford Community Council said: ldquoThe feedback is already very positive both regarding the fabulous quality of the food and the concept.ldquoOur delivery team worked quickly and observed all protocols to deliver the food to households. Wersquore gathering more feedback as we look to provide this on a weekly basis.This week, the team has also been sourcing face coverings for volunteers, to offer them extra confidence when undertaking tasks on behalf of households.Lanterne Rouge donated a supply of lsquobuffsrsquo and local resident and designer Ellie Thomson is making the coverings from her home.The community council said a request for cotton fabric, thread and elastic generated a fantastic response and they are currently trying to source additional elastic.They have also written to Homes For Le Housing Partnership, which oversees social housing flats in the village, after discovering families living there were unable to use their drying greens as gardens.They said: ldquoWe are very lucky in Gford to have a lot of open green space surrounding us.ldquoWe became aware through some tenants in social housing flats that they are unable to use drying greens as garden space for their children.ldquoWe have written to Homes For Le to ask that this situation is revisited so all children can have access to safe outdoor space on their doorstep.ldquoWe received a positive response from the organisation and hope that the guidance can be claried to benefit families in the village.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers are looking to the future to ensure people continue to receive assistance once lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A squad of volunteers in Haddington have been helping with everything from collecting food and prescriptions to walking dogs and simply providing someone for people to talk to.However, the resilience team is now planning for the future to ensure there are still plenty of volunteers available as lockdown is eased.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, has been at the heart of the resiliency efforts.He said: ldquoWe are now starting to put plans together for coming out of quarantine.ldquoFor a lot of us in the coming weeks, we will be coming out of lockdown but for our elderly residents they will probably still be in lockdown.ldquoWe are starting to plan to make sure everybody is taken care of post lockdown.Currently, many of the volunteers are off their work and able to help throughout the town.However, as businesses reopen and peopleto work, it reduces the amount of free time people have.Chris said it was important to ensure there were still volunteers available to help people who continued to be at home.The group experienced an increase in calls in the last week, with the community council vice-chairman putting it down to many people reaching the end of the month in terms of their wages.He said: ldquoFor some folk it was the end of the month and we were getting an increase in calls about food.ldquoWe have done a few things over the weekend and a couple of things to make sure people have good food, that they are covered and they are not starving themselves.Chris praised the efforts of Our Community Kitchen, who are based in the townrsquos bowling club.The team of volunteers are delivering hot meals to people throughout the town to ensure no-one is going hungry.One other issue Chris pointed to was the increased need in terms of help with gardening.He added: ldquoWith the rain and sunshine over the past week, peoplersquos gardens have started growing.ldquoWe have got in touch with some gardeners, who are going out to help people this week.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   , between am and pm.Macmerry. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirTHE Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Resilience Team are encouraging local residents to continue making pom poms, and are on the lookout for more supplies.In the past two weeks,  craft packs containing equipment necessary to make the pom poms have been distributed, with a number of adults joining in alongside the villagesrsquo children.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, told the Courier that volunteers have put ribbons up along the school gates for people to hang their finished pom poms from.He said: ldquoWersquove had about  packs handed out already and people have started making them.ldquoPeople are encouraged to go along to the school and tie their pom poms to the ribbons.He added: ldquoSince itrsquos started itrsquos become quite colourful and is really nice to see.ldquoThe whole point is to show off community support it will also show and encourage people who are from Macmerry or travelling through that we are supporting frontline workers, whether that be from the NHS, emergency service workers or supermarket staff.ldquoWe are trying to bring back that feel-good factor into the villages, when all we seem to have is bad news.One resident has decided to hang plastic balls of dferent colours outside her house as part of the project.Anyone willing to donate wool, of any quality although double knit is preferred, or anyone needing assistance is asked to call  .Collection or pick up of wool donations can also be arranged.Meanwhile, the resilience team were joined by a couple of new volunteers in the past week, and they will help to deliver the continuing resilience effort.Stevie said the resilience group have put together a contingency plan, should the virusin the future, which will allow the effort to start back up again more quickly and smoothly.He said: ldquoWersquove put a kind of plan in place, forthis all goes away then comes back again.ldquoWe now have an admin system that could be started upneeded.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, atfacebook groups   andtwitter MacmerryTeamPencaitland. Picture: Google MapsPencaitlandTHE response from residents in Pencaitland and its surrounding area to an appeal for volunteers has been described as ldquophenomenal by community council chairman Ralph Averbuch.Before lockdown had even been introduced, Pencaitland Community Council was preparing for what was coming with an early call for help.Now they have  volunteers working in a resilience network of support for the communityrsquos most vulnerable families and residents.Ralph said: ldquoOn March , it was already looking like we were approaching unprecedented events in modern times.ldquoIt was still a week away from local schools being closed and social distancing really kicking in however, unprecedented times require unprecedented measures and in Pencaitland and District that involved a call for volunteers.ldquoWe needed to be ready, and quickly, for whatever was coming.ldquoMost calls for community participation in ordinary times generate next to no response.ldquoPeople are busy with their own lives and family work concerns so lsquocommunityrsquo, for most, almost always takes a back seat.ldquoYet, when the call went out for volunteers, the response was nothing short of phenomenal.ldquoWithin  hours we had  people signed up and ready to do whatever needed to be done.ldquoFrom this start, we were able to begin a process of organising volunteers into geographic clusters, each with their own lead co-ordinators.ldquoNothing like this has happened in any of our letimes, yet, when the situation really demanded that people step up and be counted, there was no shortage of volunteers willing and able to help, from people in their teens to those in their s.ldquoWe are now a resilience network of . Had I been asked at the start how many people would come forward Irsquod have thought Irsquod be able to count them on one hand.ldquoThe good news is when itrsquos really important and people know it, there is no shortage of volunteers wanting to help solve our problems.Contact detailsAnyone living in or around the Pencaitland area and seeking assistance, or just wanting to help out, in the first instance can call Community Council chair Ralph on   or email him at covid@pencaitland.org.Additionally, Pencaitland  District Coronavirus Emergency Helpers have a Facebook page ndash facebook groups   ndash where you can get in touchyou want to help with the massive volunteer effort.Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT and Elphinstone Community Council is starting to think about how it will continue delivering its resilience effort once lockdown restrictions start to be relaxed.Member Mike Falconer is the grouprsquos single point of contact and is overseeing the local resilience effort.He told the Courier that, once restrictions begin to lt, people will still need support so the resilience effort will still be needed, something he said could be described as ldquocontingency planning.He said: ldquoWe canrsquot just stop the need is still going to be there.ldquoThe lt of restrictions is going to be gradual [rather than all at once] and we need to think how we are going to manage and maintain the resilience effort and some sort of support.He added that there is not a plan in place, as such, but the community council ldquohas got its eye on it.Meanwhile, it is business as usual and residents who need assistance continue to get the help they need.Mike said: ldquoItrsquos exactly the same and we are carrying on doing what we are doing, delivering food, walking dogs and picking up prescriptions.ldquoWersquove got a routine established and are just carrying on delivering it until we are told to stop.The resilience effort is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsThose who need assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie  Port Seton continue to help local residents, and more than pound, has been donated to the cause by iniduals and groups since lockdown began.The resilience effort is being led by Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council, whose chairman, Bryan Hickman, said: ldquoPeople have been so generous and the money is being used to purchase food.Some of the grouprsquos volunteers are asking for donations of wool, to make blankets which will be given to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and used for premature babies.To donate items, contact Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council via email at cockenzieandportseton@hotmail.The resilience group has received a donation from the Walk With Scott Foundation and will deliver craft activity packs alongside its breakfast packs on Wednesdays, helping to keep local residents entertained while at home.To mark VE Day and allow residents to celebrate in lockdown, afternoon tea boxes consisting of items such as sandwiches, scones, cakes and tea will be delivered.Bryan is also keen to get copies of the Courier delivered to elderly and vulnerable residents, as groups in Haddington and North Berwick are doing.The community councilrsquos resilience team are also sending out hot meals and providing food packs to local children who would usually receive free school meals.This is being run from the Port Seton Centre, supported by centre staff.So far,  lunches and  breakfast packs are going out every day.More than , meals are going out to the local community every week.Last week, the centre started receiving a delivery from FareShare, a charity that delivers surplus food from supermarkets to charities and organisations for those in need.Contact detailsAnyone who needs assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  .East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonRESIDENTS of four rural villages are being reminded help is there for themthey need it.Contacts have been set up in Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and Bolton to offer people assistance during the coronavirus pandemic.Shena Jamieson, who lives in Bolton, told the Courier it had been reasonably quiet in terms of the number of calls but stressed they were there to help.She said: ldquoPeople should ring us.ldquoDonrsquot feel that you are being a nuisance or wonder whether it is the right person.ldquoWe can always put you in touch with the right person.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryITrsquoS business as usual for the resilience effort in Longniddry which is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.SheilaJamieson said she is still receiving some queries, such as people with toothache asking the best place to get help.She added that there have not been many shopping requests, as a lot of residents are getting their food through online deliveries.Sheila said: ldquoAlthough we do have quite a lot of older people, we are quite fortunate to have a great community.ldquoVolunteers are also helping their neighbours and friends along with enquiries as they come in.ldquoItrsquos pretty steady and we are just going on as normal.One Longniddry resident has started offering a dogwalking service for those unable to take their pooch on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Volunteers are happy to pick up prescriptions, though the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those aged  and over.Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghRESILIENT Musselburgh has nearly hit the  mark with the number of volunteers who have joined its emergency efforts during the Covid- pandemic.The co-ordinating team have now settled into their new base at the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre, after their recent move from Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Distribution of food and prescriptions to the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall is continuing.Local residents are being supported through referrals from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre and callsto the Resilient Musselburgh dedicated phone number on  .Last week alone,  preschool lunch packs,  meals and  lunches were distributed.Up until last Friday,  soup and sandwich deliveries were made thanks to the Mercat Grill in Whitecraig, which started the initiative on April .Musselburgh Area Partnership, working in partnership with Hickory, started distributing meals on April  and, so far, they have provided  meals to vulnerable people in the local community.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, who is co-ordinating the volunteer response, said: ldquoIt is so heartening to see the willingness and effort given to the community by the volunteers.ldquoThey have happily gone over and above by uplting and delivering repeat prescriptions from ious locations, including uplts from outside Musselburgh, and are continuing to deliver emergency food packs and pre-school lunches.ldquoWithout them the community response would not happen.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS Community Council has established a hardship fund for people who are struggling as the lockdown continues.Community council chairman Brian Weddell said last week had been the busiest yet for the resilience team, with volunteers managing to deliver leaflets throughout the Pans advertising the Scotmid free shopping delivery service, and several volunteers now doing daily dog walks for local people self isolating.More of the volunteers are also helping the work at the Pennypit Pantry by collecting groceries being donated by local supermarkets and delivering meals to local people.Last week, the Pantry provided  meals to a mix of elderly residents who are shielding and many families looking after young children currently off school.While demand for support has been high, anyone needing help should contact the Pennypit Pantry on   or email lornabellany@gmailThe hardship fund has been established for people finding it increasingly dficult as the lockdown continues, and anyone needing help should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailRegular information is also posted on both the Prestonpans Community Council Facebook page or their dedicated Prestonpans Resilience Facebook page.Brian said: ldquoOur resilience team are also grateful for the support we are receiving from Sandy Baptie and Kevin Sewell in East Lothian Councilrsquos Resilient Communities team, who send out daily updates which provide useful information on what is happening in other resilience teams and the additional support that is available.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or emailprestonpansresilience@gmail

title: seek-help-medical-emergencies
story: YESTERDAY, May , marked the th anniversary of VEDay, remembering the surrender of the Nazis and the end of the Second World War.I hope you joined me in paying tribute to surviving veterans and in commemorating those lost during the conflict.I am very grateful for the enduring peace achieved across Europe since .Although we might not have been able to take part in our usual commemorations, there was an online service led by Legion Scotland and Poppyscotland, which included a message from children and families currently learning at home and a video message of thanks from the First Minister.I am glad that measures were taken to honour this important anniversary, and to remember those who lost their lives.There has been a large reduction in the number of stroke patients, with AEs and stroke wards signicantly quieter since the beginning of the Covid- pandemic.We must not forget that a stroke is a medical emergency and,you see someone displaying stroke symptoms, it is still important to immediately dial .This is not the only medical emergency that you should seek support on ndashyou have any urgent symptoms that are not coronavirus related, you should still seek assistance from a GP or hospital.The NHS is still here for us and will continue to support those who need it.The Scottish Government has recommended thatyou are in an enclosed public space, such as a supermarket, then you should consider using something to cover your face.As well as this, you must also maintain a two-metre distance from those outside your household.It is important to note that covering your face does not necessarily mean that you need a medical grade face mask ndash something such as a scarf would also suffice.As we continue working together to overcome the Covid- pandemic, it is important that we continue to take social distancing measures seriously and I would recommend keeping up to date with the Scottish Government and NHS advice.

title: must-return-fairer-world-says-mp
story: MINDS are turning to le post-coronavirus, though itrsquoll still be a while before lockdown is even partially lted. But some of the enforced changes have suited some.Irsquove a few friends nearing retirement age and, enjoying the change in pace of le, have decided to retire early. It doesnrsquot suit everyone and itrsquos not available for many but, for those to whom it does apply, I say good luck.But there are other aspects that apply to us all. The Irish President, Michael D Higgins, made a remarkable speech about how both a better country and a fairer world need to come from this. Those sentiments and that ambition must apply here, as well as across the Irish Sea.When this is over, itrsquos about rewarding fairly those who have, not just throughout this crisis but always, worked hard in dficult circumstances.Itrsquos decent pay and conditions, as much as applause, that NHS staff, carers and council workers deserve. Despite the rhetoric about all of us being in this together, the poor have been suffering the most and that too must change.As well as in our economy and society though, the change must also be in our natural environment. Theof wildle has been joyful and the improvement in air quality a revelation.The latterrsquos something wersquove often taken for granted but for those with a lung or heart problem itrsquos a daily concern.The images of pollution fading across countries is astonishing but the freshness wersquore feeling in our lungs is something we need to retain.We canrsquot simply go back to le the way it was. When the coronavirus crisis is over, the climate change crisis will remain.We need to cherish the improvements that have come about, but remember the huge challenges that still exist, in ensuring our planetrsquos habitable for future generations.It wonrsquot be either easy or simple but the sacrices made by so many and the limited pleasures wersquove had as a result of it, must be a spur to deliver that better country and fairer world.

title: former-power-station-site-become-covid-19-testing-centre
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that the former Cockenzie Power Station site will be opened and operated by the military as part of the UK Governments Covid- testing programme.No date for when it will start operations has been revealed but it is likely to be within the next week as testing is ramped up as part of plans to ease the current lockdown.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating in Musselburgh since the start of April.The site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower and is currently being marketed for economic investment, was offered up as a potential testing location by the council.The unit will be managed and staffed by military personnel, who would be responsible for its safe operation.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site whilst the facility is closed.The council said it expects the facility to operate as a self-contained, drive-through facility. People will remain in their vehicle whilst being tested. Initially, it is understood it would operate over two, three-day periods.Tom Reid, the councils head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located."The former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel."This facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-."East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.The facility will provide tests for key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms.It is understood key workers and their family members will be eligible for testing.Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via thehttps:self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stations famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September, , two years after it had closed. The power station had opened in .

title: costa-coffee-starbucks-mcdonalds-get-green-light-reopen-drive-thrus
story: Ahead of an anticipated relaxation of the lockdown rules, the Environment Secretary has said drive-thru restaurants such as McDonaldrsquos are ldquomade for social distancing.At the Downing Street press conference on Friday, George Eustice said it was safe for takeaway food shops to reopen.Many familiar high street chains including McDonaldrsquos, Greggs and KFC chose to shut their doors during the lockdown.What did the Environment Secretary say When asked about fast-food stores reopening, Mr Eustice said: ldquoI think our view is that probably a McDonaldrsquos drive-thru is made for the social distancing situation we are in, in that people do not leave their car, they place their order and someone passes a bag of food to them at the end through a kiosk.Unlike many other businesses, fast-food outlets were not mandated to close during the lockdown.Some chains have begun to reopenSome restaurants have begun the process of reopening, with KFC opening around  of its branches for delivery or drive-thru.McDonaldrsquos has conducted trials on reopening stores, with  restaurants opening for deliveries from next week.Askedoutlets could have stayed open during the crisis, Mr Eustice said: ldquoWhile clearly restaurants and pubs had to close, we were quite keen to keep that capacity to be able to do takeaway food for people.He suggested reduced footfall in town centres, staff anxiety and a sense of what was ldquosocially acceptable given the stay-at-home message had led to places such as McDonaldrsquos and KFC closing.Mr Eustice added: ldquoI think it is quite possible for these venues to reopen and reopen safely, we never mandated that they should close.ldquoI think some of those food-to-go businesses will probably be seeking to learn lessons from what supermarkets have done as they consider tentatively reopening.New safety measures have been introduced at food outletsBefore reopening, the McDonaldrsquos restaurants will be deep cleaned, while new safety measures will be introduced such as Perspex screens and floor markings.Staff will also receive protective equipment, such as non-medical grade face masks, and have their temperatures taken with ldquocontactless thermometers before shts.Earlier this month Greggs pulled back on plans to reopen its first sites to the public next week over fears it could attract crowds.The highly popular title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: mcdonalds-reveal-safety-rules-customers-ahead-gradual-reopening
story: The move comes after announcing a delivery-only service, followed by the reopening of a number of drive-thrus later this month.What are McDonalds doing McDonaldrsquos is to reopen its first  drive-through restaurants as early as next week as it pushes forward with its reopening plans.It comes as fast food rival Subway reopens more than  of its UK stores on Tuesday for delivery and takeaway as it serves customers for the first time since the lockdown.McDonaldrsquos will open its first  pilot restaurants from am on Wednesday, May , for deliveries only.The fast food chain said it country director for Subway UK and Ireland, said: ldquoEverybody in our Subway family and the wider communities they serve, has shown great resilience in adapting to these challenging times that we communities and frontline workers, who have helped us all so much in recent weeks.ldquoThe weeks and months ahead will continue to be challenging for everyone and Subway will play its part in title: donations-pouring-help-north-berwicks-scottish-seabird-centre
story: Started last Wednesday , the centre launched the urgent appeal with an aim to raise pound, by the end of July, which will help see it through lockdown after Covid- closed the attractions visitor centre and stopped its income.So far, pound, has been raised on the online JustGiving page but almost pound, has been donated in total.Opened  years ago, the charity is under threat and faces closurethe required amount is not raised.Those at the Seabird Centre hoped their target could be reached through grant and government funding, but without signicant public funding this will not be possible.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre said: ldquoIn response to Covid-, we launched the first public appeal in the  year history of our charity on May , with the backing of both Chris Packham and Simon King.ldquoWe are delighted with the generosity already shown by the public and our loyal members with nearly pound, already donated.ldquoThe warm messages of support we have received have given the team a real morale boost and hope for the future too.ldquoWe still have a big challenge to meet our pound, target by the end of July, through a combination of the public appeal and emergency funding applications but we remain hopeful for the future. Thank you to all who have shown their support.Anyone who wants to make a donation can do so at www.justgiving campaign SeabirdSOS

title: lothian-buses-announces-changes-services
story: Its number  service, which links parts of Musselburgh to the west side of Edinburgh, now sees frequency improved to every  minutes from Monday-Saturday during the day.There is minor timetable changes on the  service which goes from Tranent to Edinburgh through Prestonpans and Musselburgh.On EastCoast Buses, the  service, which goes from Dunbar to Edinburgh through places such as Haddington, Tranent and Wallyford, sees daytime frequency increased to  minutes from Edinburgh to Haddington, the hourly service to and from Dunbar will be maintained.On the  Pencaitland to Edinburgh service, there is a revised timetable to coordinate with the . The last journey from Edinburgh and Pencaitland has been withdrawn.A revised timetable has been introduced on the  North Berwick to Edinburgh service, including an additional morning peak journey from Longniddry to Edinburgh on Mondays and Saturdays.There is currently no change on the  service from Musselburgh to Roslin.Nigel Serafini, interim managing director at Lothian Buses, said: ldquoOver the past six weeks, our services have provided vital links for those who require to travel for work or to obtain essentials such as food and medicine."Our teams have continued to monitor customer travel patterns and have listened to both customer and colleague feedback."Today we are announcing additional revisions to our Critical Services Network which will better meet the needs of key workers and those for whom travel remains essential.ldquoEvery team across our business has continued to go above and beyond to provide these vital services and my thanks go to each and every one of them both on the frontline and behind the scenes."I would also like to thank our customers who have shown an enormous amount of support and understanding throughout what continues to be an incredibly challenging operational time.

title: hollywood-stars-appear-outlander-returns-east-lothian
story: Filming for the worldwide hit took place in spring last year but details about what was shot could not be revealed until after its episode had aired.East Linton is no stranger to the Outlander cast and crew as Preston Mill has also been used as a filming location.While Outlander star Sam Heughan ndash who was not in East Linton this time ndash was part of a fundraising campaign which helped raise pound, to repair the millrsquos water wheel.The Mart, formerly a market place for local farmers and traders, is now an arts and events venue. It had been booked for weddings this summer, but these have been delayed until next year due to the coronavirus outbreak.Outlanderrsquos programmersquos location manager contacted Melissa Wearmouth, The Martrsquos site manager, to arrange the filming.Melissa told the Courier: ldquoThey wanted something with our shape of building and were finding it hard to come across.Our building is the last one of its kind in Scotland so is quite unique .ldquoOne of the guys spoke to a friend and mentioned us and then the people from the show got in contact.Crew were there for three weeks to set up equipment for only one dayrsquos filming. Stars including Billy Boyd, of Lord of the Rings fame, Edward Speleers , James Dohertyand Andy Apollowere spotted.Melissa added that The Martrsquos car park was full and there were a lot of people about, such as security, catering and lighting staff.Filming also attracted some fans of the show, who hoped to catch a glimpse of their favourite characters.Work to restore the building, which included laying a new floor and painting the exterior, had just been finished.Melissa said: ldquoThey were pretty easy going. They had to change little things, like laying an old floor.ldquoWe put the new floor on top of the old cobbles and put in a glass centrepiece so you could still see the cobbles in the middle we needed a new floor for events and stuff.ldquoIt took us a long time to restore the building and its original features we tried to keep as many of the older features as possible.ldquo[The Outlander team] put a temporary floor on top so they could have dirt and things like that ndash they needed it to look more like a tavern.The Mart is featured in series five of the show, which is out now on Amazon Prime, at the end of episode two, which was first broadcast on February .Melissa admitted she had not watched the show previously but does now!

title: former-royal-marine-conquers-everest-back-garden
story: Kenny Simm, , climbed a rope and abseiled down it in his garden on the Lennoxlove Estate, near Haddington,  times, completing a total of , metres, the same height as Mount Everest in the Himalayas.He completed his challenge over  hours, starting at am on April  and finishing at am on April .He did not sleep in between but did occasionally stop for refreshment breaks.Kenny said: ldquoI think it was just a spur of the moment thing.ldquoI came up with the idea four days before I started it so didnrsquot do any prior training.ldquoWhen I was with the Marines I went off-shore and saw all these challenges people were doing and thought it would be a good thing to do.ldquoI wanted to do something a bit dferent and a bit special for charity and also to challenge myself.He had a four-metre-long rope attached to the side of his shed that he intended to use for the challenge. . . until the rope snapped during a testing session.Kenny was climbing the rope at the time and fell four metres to the ground but was not badly hurt.He then contacted a friend who came to his house and built an eight-metre-high scaffolding structure in his garden specially for the challenge.Every time he landed on solid ground, he would record his run to make sure he completed the , journeys needed to reach the required distance:  times up and  times down.While the journey down was a simple abseil, Kenny, who used to be on the British bobsleigh team and competed in strongman events, had to pull himself to the top.Kenny, who is originally from Shetland and is dad to seven-year-old Hugo, was a Royal Marine for  years.He now works for Viridor as a mechanical fitter at the Dunbar energy recovery facility.He said: ldquoI think the Royal Marines helped a little bit. Being part of the Marines is like an exclusive club and I had that prior training.He added: ldquoNot sleeping was the hardest bit. When I asked my we about it she said, lsquoYoursquore not going to do thatrsquo.ldquoShe set an alarm every two hours and was checking on me to make sure I was still alive. I made pasta and made sure to keep my food and drink intake up. I had music playing too.ldquoIt was pretty tough, especially the first two hours. I kept thinking lsquowhat kind of challenge is this going to bersquo and wondered how I was going to do it for  hours.ldquoThere was added pressure because we had highlighted it on social media.Kenny is raising money for the NHS who, he says, are ldquodoing amazing work, are ldquorisking their lives and ldquohave never had that [proper] recognition.Hersquos raised almost pound, so far.His mother-in-law Carol Fitzgerald is a retired NHS worker and sister-in-law Karen McQuade works in a coronavirus ward at Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh.Hearing their stories also inspired him.It took Kenny two days to fully recover from his challenge, which gave him blisters and cramps in his arms and legs.He added: ldquoIrsquom glad I did it but I wonrsquot be doing it again.Anyone wishing to donate can do so at www.justgiving fundraising kennysimm-climbeverestfor-nhs

title: veteran-musicians-mark-ve-day-doorsteps
story: Alastair Knowles BEM played the lsquoLast Postrsquo on the bugle from the front door of his Stoneyhill home and pipe major Stewart Braby performed lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at the Mall near his house in Inveresk Road last Friday.Mr Knowles said he was asked by Iain Clark, from Musselburgh, a Depute Lieutenant of East Lothian, to mark the end of the two -minute silence at am that day by ringing the bell at Northesk Church in Musselburgh, which he duly did.Mr Knowles also heard from Bruno Peek, VE Day  Pageant Master, who was keen to keep as much of the national programme going as possible amidst the coronavirus pandemic.The events were arranged to mark the th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day ndash the day celebrating the formal acceptance by the Allies of the Nazisrsquo unconditional surrender of their armed forces, on Tuesday,  May , marking the end of the Second World War in Europe.Buglers and trumpeters were still urged to sound the lsquoLast Postrsquo, as planned, at .pm, and pipers to play lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at pm.Mr Knowles followed his uncle into the Boysrsquo Brigade in the mid-s.Since then he has become a key part of the group, becoming a bugler and leading drummer in the Penicuik and Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band.He was Town Champion at the  Riding of the Marches in Musselburgh, before being appointed chairman of the  event.He is also a former president of the Old Musselburgh Club.He received the BEM for services to the community in Musselburgh.Mr Braby, pipe major with the Penicuik  Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band, is also pipe major of the massed bands at the Boysrsquo Brigade Beating Retreat at Edinburgh Castle.Mr Knowles said: ldquoLater in the evening my we Lily and I, as our daily exercise outing, took a walk to Northesk, where the third member of the church,Lorraine McBrearty, added her contribution with the singing of lsquoWersquoll Meet Againrsquo only yards from her home on Bridge Street at pm.He added: ldquoIt was a busy but fulfilling day.

title: bid-transform-former-coastguard-building-rejected
story: Planners ruled the redesign of the building, on Lamer Street, Dunbar, would give any occupant just  square metres of living kitchen space.They said the lack of garden and amenity meant it would be too small to meet standards set out in their own policy.The plans to turn the station into a one-bedroom house were lodged after it went on the market for pound, after the emergency service moved.Plans lodged with the council proposed creating a living area downstairs and an upstairs bedroom with a balcony which would look out onto the sea.However revised plans used part of the downstairs area for parking and cut the space available.A report by an East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officer said: ldquoGiven the small area of the ground floor and that within that area the wet room and stairs would be provided, the actual living kitchen area of the house would amount to around  square metres.The plans were refused on the ground of its constrained nature which would allow neither privacy nor amenity to occupants.

title: tributes-paid-caring-gran
story: Irene Grant spent last Friday saying farewell to her mother Mary Jane Gouldingat a funeral parlour before ing for afternoon tea in the garden of her home on Rope Walk, Prestonpans.She was preparing to spend the day alone but Musselburghrsquos Yarnbombers group ndash famous for their wool-based community art displays ndash had arranged to leave lsquoJock and Jeannie,rsquo a knitted lsquocouplersquo, who were due to have pride of place at a street party at Musselburghrsquos Brunton Hall, outside her home.The public event to celebrate the th anniversary of VE Day was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic but Irene, who was brought up in Musselburgh, was determined to mark the occasion the way her -year-old mum would have wanted.Irene went to her doorstep at am to observe the nationrsquos twominute silence before she and her neighbours had afternoon tea in their own gardens as well as a social distance singalong featuring an emotional rendition of lsquoWersquoll Meet Again.Irene, a member of the yarnbombers, decorated her garden with knitted cakes, a lsquogrow your own vegetablesrsquo display and put up bunting ndash in keeping with the grouprsquos tradition of brightening up Musselburgh with dferent knitted displays since the Riding of the Marches in .A founder member of Musselburghrsquos Clark Concert Party, she said: ldquoI was at the undertaker making arrangements for mum and came home to Jock and Jeannie sitting on my steps. It was an amazing surprise ndash although I got the fright of my le. You have no idea how much it cheered me up and gave me a much needed laugh. My friends in the Yarnbombers decided I needed company. I was determined to go ahead with a wee party, although I live on my own and have no one to celebrate with. Mum was in a nursing home and the family had not seen her for eight weeks nor were we permitted to be with her at the end.Mary, who was resident at Drummond Grange Nursing Home at Lasswade, took a ldquosevere decline two weeks before her death.Irene said: ldquoShe was not eating or drinking. Everyone thought she had lsquoturned her back to the wallrsquo with being in isolation. Her attending doctor thought she would test her for Covid and we got the news that it was positive. Mum had shown no symptoms whatsoever. She died on Sunday, May .Mary was born in Nova Scotia, Canada, in March , where her parents George and Mary Grahamhad emigrated to after her father was laid off during the General Strike of .They ed to Prestonpans four years later and Mary, her two sisters and three brothers, enjoyed ldquoan extremely happy childhood at their home in Nethershot.Her dad was a miner at Prestongrange colliery all his working le.Mary married her husband Jim Goulding on March , , at Newcraighall Church, and Irene and her sister Janice had a happy childhood growing up at Galt Crescent in Musselburgh.Mary worked as a carer home help until her retirement.After she and Jim orced, she moved to South Street where she lived for a few years before moving to amenity housing on Hercus Loan.She was diagnosed with vascular dementia in  and, in , went into care, latterly becoming a resident at Drummond Grange.Irene said: ldquoThis became her home and our family will never be able to thank the staff there enough for the love and care they showed her, particularly in these past weeks. One observation about the staff came from the undertaker who said lsquothey had dressed your mum in her Sunday best and she looked gorgeousrsquo.She added: ldquoWe cannot be sad that mum has gone because of the torment her mind was in for so long but we are all devastated with the circumstances in which she went ndash not seeing any of us for so long. For the first time in any of our lives, we missed being with her on her birthday and on Motherrsquos Day. It is such a tragic way to end a long fruitful le. She was so caring to everyone and had a wicked sense of humour which transcended the generations.A spokesperson for the nursing home said: ldquoWe would like to extend our deepest condolences to the family and friends who have lost a loved one in this awful pandemic. Mary was a much loved member of the community who treated everyone with kindness and respect, and will be dearly missed.Mary had bequeathed her body to medical science but this cannot happen in the current circumstances, so her funeral took place at Seafield Crematorium on Wednesday, which was attended by her immediate family.She is survived by her daughters Irene and Janice, four grandchildren, her sisters Isobel and Georgie, and many friends particularly Faye and Rod Gibson.The family have set up The Mary Goulding Celebration Fund to raise money for Alzheimer Scotland.To donate go to https:marygoulding.muchloved

title: covid-19-testing-centre-opening-former-power-station-site
story: The drive-through centre will be operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve unitsin Scotland and will carry out tests on key workers from tomorrowto Monday with plans toagain in two weeksrsquo time.East Lothian Council confirmed it had made the site available as part of the UKGovernmentrsquos Covid- testing programme.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre since the start of April.The Cockenzie site, bought by the local authority from ScottishPower, is currently being marketed for economic investment.In preparation of the appointment-only testing unitrsquos opening, signs and cones have been put in place to direct drivers.The centre will re-open on Saturday, May , through to Monday, June , and is providing back-up support to a main testing centre at EdinburghAirport.Key workers who have symptoms, or have a member of their household displaying symptoms, can self-refer to the site through the UK Governmentrsquos online portal.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site while the facility is closed.The council said it expects the unit to operate as a self-contained, drivethrough facility.People will remain in their vehicle while being tested.It is not known how many tests can be carried out at the site each day.Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel.ldquoThis facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-. East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move to open the centre at Cockenzie.He said: ldquoI have been calling on the Scottish Government to follow the World Health Organisationrsquos advice and ramp up the amount of testing we are doing for over a month now, so I welcome this new centre in Cockenzie and hope it will mean local key workers do not have to travel so far to access a test.ldquoA signicant increase in testing capacity will be essentialthe Scottish Governmentrsquos plans for testing, tracing and isolating are to be successful and this centre will contribute to the expansion needed.The move was also welcomed by local community councils.Bryan Hickman, chairperson of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased that the site is being used for a testing unit. It seems very suitable and hopefully it will help in getting this terrible virus under control.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoThe former power station site at Preston Links is an ideal location for a Covid testing site for East Lothian. It is remote enough from local communities with plenty of space to ensure government distancing regulations are maintained.The drive-through testing centres are available to people who live less than  minutes drive from them and are in addition to NHS Scotland testing.Scottish Government guidelines on who can apply for a test at the UK Government mobile testing centres are on their website.For a full list of those eligible to go bit.ly csBii Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via the self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stationrsquos famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September , two years after it had closed.

title: letter-walker-left-totally-shaken-incident
story: We y our routes but on this particular day we decided to walk along the road which goes to West Barns from Yosemite Park.We turned left and went under the bridge which takes you onto the road to Spott Roundabout.Just as we had turned left to do so, all of a sudden at least five dogs appeared from nowhere and leapt on to the road from the field and a black large Labrador then came running towards me and jumped up and put its claws on my arm which meant its face was next to mine.I am frightened of large dogs and let out a scream whereupon another large coffee cream-coloured dog came running towards me.The ownereventually appeared and shouted on the dogs to come to him but, of course, they didnrsquot.I was so scared and shouted on him that the dogs should all be on leashes due to the virus and that dogs can carry the virus.He initially apologised then got very aggressive, shouting that I should stay at home and mind my own business at my age.I told him I was going to report him and I got another mouthful of abuse.If I had been a child I would certainly have been knocked over at least.Also,I hadnrsquot been wearing a long-sleeved top my arm would have been clawed.This person drove a white van stating it belonged to a drainage company and was obviously out letting the dogs do their ldquobusiness in the farmerrsquos fields.I presume because all the parks have been closed off this is the easiest option for people with multiple dogs.We are both very keen walkers but this has left me so shaken for the total disregard of the majority of us who are complying with the lockdown rules.Surely it could be made mandatory that all dog walkers keep their dogs on leashes for everyonersquos safety and hygiene  The number of dog walkers using Winterfield golf course at the moment is shameful.Name and address supplied

title: dog-found-layby-maggots-put-sleep
story: The Scottish SPCA is appealing for information after the dog was picked up from a layby on the B between East Linton and North Berwick on Wednesday.Emma Phillips, Scottish SPCA inspector, told the Courier: ldquoThe male dog was found collapsed with a wound to his back end.ldquoHe had fly strike and a maggot infestation in the open wound.ldquoWe immediately took him for veterinary attention but the poor boy was suffering so much that the vet made the dficult decision to put him to sleep.ldquoHe was black and white, overweight, and had a green slip collar on.Now, the Scottish SPCA is encouraging anyone with information to come forward.Emma said: ldquoWe are hoping someone recognises him as we are keen to speak to the people responsible for the condition he was found in.ldquoIf anyone has any information about who the dog belonged to or how he was abandoned in this way, please contact our animal helpline on   .ldquoCalls can be treated confidentially.Abandoning an animal is an offence under the Animal Health and WelfareAct .Anyone found guilty of doing so can expect to be banned from keeping animals for a fixed period or le.

title: tui-unveil-plan-summer-holidays---hope-fly
story: Heres what you need to know.Which destinations will TUI fly to The holiday operator wants to resume package deals to destinations that are considered ldquosafe, and have passed a series of health checks developed by TUI.Majorca is the destination that is likely to be first, as hotels in the region have been tested and could be opened immediately to host tourists, Friedrich Joussen, TUI Group CEO said.Several other European holiday spots could also be among the list of destinations, including Greece, Cyprus, Croatia and Bulgaria, all of which Joussen described as ldquowell prepared for summer tourism.Austria and Denmark were named as possible destinations as well, being among a number of EU countries that are starting to reopen their borders.However, the roll out of flights to Europe will have to be done gradually, and in line with both government guidance on travel and the lting of EU borders.Holidays to Europe are also likely to be hindered by the  day quarantine period being enforced by many countries, with tourists faced with spending two weeks in quarantine in Spain before being able to start their holiday.In contrast, visits to France and Ireland will be unhindered by such rules.How will TUI make its hotels safe The package holiday specialist has outlined a ten-point plan, detailing how hotels will operate after lockdown is lted.Plans include restrictions on its popular self-service buffets, which are due to be reduced to a minimum.Instead, food and beverages will be served to guests by staff wearing protective masks, where possible.The measures will be implemented across all of the companyrsquos own-brand hotels, and will also be made ldquoavailable to joint-venture and partner hotels.Guests will face limits on their range of entertainment and activities, with football tournaments set to be banned.Only events, sports and entertainment that involve a small number of participants, and without close contact, will be made available.Other measures include online check-ins, maintaining social distancing in public areas, such as gyms and corridors, and reduced capacity in restaurants, with longer opening hours to spread guest usage.There will also be an increase in disinfectant dispensers throughout TUIrsquos hotels, and ldquoextensive new cleaning practices will be implemented for rooms.TUI said that its new  point plan is in addition to statutory regulations, which will be put in place at all of the holiday destinations where it operates.The safety measures it has set out for after lockdown form part of a wider package that includes plans in its retail outlets, as well as on flights, transfers to hotels, local excursions, and cruises.

title: sadness-century-old-tree-ormiston-main-street-felled
story: The sycamore tree was felled on Monday, with a road closure and traffic ersions required between am and .pm due to the size of the tree.In January, the Courier reported that the ft-tall tree would be cut down as it was rotten and thought dangerous.However, an aerial inspection and reassessment of the tree led to that decision being reversed.Instead, a major crown reduction to reduce the weight of the treersquos limbs and the overall sail area of the tree was planned.But further recent inspections found more deterioration of the roots and lower stem of the tree.These recent discoveries, along with other issues in its upper crown, meant the only safe option was to remove the whole tree and replant it, said the authorities.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThere has been talk within the community of seeking to use the trunk stem somewhere in the village but nothing has been decided yet.Scott Gillies, chair of Ormiston Community Council, said: ldquoItrsquos obviously sad to see it go but it was a really old tree that came down. I got a phone call last week and went to see the tree, which showed it had deteriorated further.ldquoThe bark was coming off and you could see the rot inside it.ldquoWe didnrsquot really have much of an option but to cut it down.ldquoThe tree officer doesnrsquot go around cutting trees down randomly so it had to be done it was showing signs of decay.

title: youngsters-go-extra-yard-charity
story: P pupils at The Compass School in Haddington took on the challenge of running . kilometres or . miles for charity on April  in place of the postponed London Marathon.The children, supported by their families, were delighted to be able to raise funds for the good cause.The charity, which is based near North Berwick provides caring respite breaks for people and their families living with long-term conditions.Leuchie House is currently supporting the NHS in the fight against the Covid- virus.Mark Becher, headteacher of the school on Haddingtonrsquos West Road, said: ldquoI am very proud of the children for taking on this initiative and raising funds for this important cause Leuchie House being one of the charities which the school supports on annual basis.ldquoI too put on my running shoes on the day to show support for them, although I was happy that I was not running against them as I am sure they would have left me far behind!ldquoWell done to them all!Having now broken the pound, mark, the childrenrsquos fundraising is continuing and donations can be made at www.justgiving team Formfor-

title: tranent-dj-leads-drive-donations-key-workers
story: The initiative started after a nurse from the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh approached Davie, asking for help.He posted a request on Facebook, askinglocal residents and friends were able to donate any items.Adam Cook, manager at the Asda store in Tranent, contacted Davie and suggested people could use the store as a drop-off point.While Adam and the Asda store collected items for the Royal Infirmary, Davie invited people to drop off donations for other local healthcare facilities at his home in Tranent.These items have been donated to East Lothian Community Hospital and Haddington Care Home.Davie and Adam were also involved in a collection at the Asda store in Leith for the Western General Hospital.Davie was overwhelmed with the number of donations he received and also the number of people offering support.He said: ldquoThe number of people needing help with things is such a shame.ldquoThe amount of stuff I got was amazing. The community was great and Asda was great.ldquoI thought I was finished one day and then when I came back from dropping some things off there were  or  bags at the door.ldquoPeople were offering cash and putting money in envelopes for petrol but I used the money to buy more stuff.Davie thanked the community for their kindness and support during the initiative.He added a thanks to Radio Saltire, which donated toiletries, a gesture he called ldquovery kind, and Weber Packing Solutions in Macmerry, which also made a donation.Davie said: ldquoThe response from the community was incredible.ldquoAnyone considering something similar for charity or a group, please make sure you get permission first or contact your local resilience team, who have the contacts and the experience.Davie was also collecting disposable car seat covers, hand sanitiser and hand wash for St Columbarsquos Hospice in Edinburgh.Friend and former Tranent resident Dot Baillie, who now lives in Pencaitland, knitted hundreds of small chickens, inserting an Easter egg in each. She gave Davie two bags for the community hospital.Alongside family, friends, neighbours and Weber Packing Solutions in Macmerry, she raised more than pound.Davie was able to ide Dotrsquos funds: pound to St Columbarsquos Hospice, pound to Mike Girdwoodrsquos face shields project and pound to the Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes initiative.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: new-town-top-low-carbon-location
story: The local authority has lodged its vision for the future with Scottish Ministers as they prepare to create a new National Policy Framework .But it has warned its ambitions must not be sacriced in a rush to kickstart the economy as the nation comes out of lockdown.In an opening statement to their submission, officials expressed concern that new developments may lose sight of the long-term ambition they have for the county.They tell the Scottish Government: ldquoThe current challenges brought about by coronavirus may have lasting effects on the economy.ldquoWhile demand for new development will , it is important that, in the short term, standards in new development are not prejudiced to stimulate growth.ldquoThe ambitions around climate change, ecology, health and well-being, equality, connectivity, inclusive growth and place-making remain.East Lothian Council wants the National Development designation given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in previous frameworks to be expanded to include the new town of Blindwells which is underway on nearby land, in the new NPF.The council believes that National Development status for the wider area including nearby Blindwells would support ambitions for sustainable growth and an emerging vision for the area to be an influential, innovative, healthy and carbon neutral location.And they say the larger site could become one of Scotlands top ten low carbon locations.While the boundaries of the area are still to be finalised it could stretch out to cover existing communities of Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Council spokesperson for Environment, said it was important the county continued to plan for the future during the Covid- outbreak.And he said it was important the ambitions set out before the lockdown continued to be at the heart of decisions made.He said: ldquoWe are ambitious for East Lothian and want to see it remain as a great place in which to live and work, which is well connected with good employment opportunities and sustainability principles at its heart.The local authority has asked Scottish Ministers to designate an area known as The Blindwells, Cockenzie and Climate Change Zone, as a National Development.Councillor Hampshire said: ldquoWe want to see the new settlement at Blindwells developed as a fantastic community in which to live and work.ldquoIt should be a zero emissions community embracing climate change objectives and embracing blue green infrastructure and bioersity.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site offers signicant opportunity in terms of economic development and employment and work continues to understand its potential.ldquoIn our proposal for a National Development, we are suggesting that a Climate Change Zone is created between these sites, and including parts of, neighbouring communities and sites.ldquoWe believe this wider area, part of the former East Lothian coalfield, could be one of Scotlandrsquos top  locations for low carbon, sustainable inclusive growth and we are determined to grasp the opportunity.ldquoWe are making our case in a submission to the Scottish Government and will be carrying out public engagement on the extent of our vision for the area in due course.

title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!
